{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3224159,"name":"Yuval","username":"YuvalCode","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yuvalcode/{size}/270549_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-09T21:52:05.849Z","cooked":"

Hello, I Am Yuval From Team 6741 Space Monkeys. I Am A Lead Programer And Our Team Is Getting a “Re-Brand”. In The Last Couple Of Weeks We Discussed About Implimanting Encoders, Cameras, etc… On Our Robot For The Off Season. We Did not Work With Gadgets Like That (at Least Our New Generation) Before, We Are Learning alot Of Things Right Now And we Are Doing great.

The Main Topic i come With To Here is: Does the Limelight 2+ Can Detect Objects Like the 2023 Cube?

We tried Multiple calibrations With The Pipeline And Threshold But No use, The Limelight 2+ Can Detect The Cube But it also Detects Things Like Human Hands, Specific Color Objects and etc…

Is It Possible To Make The Limelight 2+ Detect Only The Object We Would Want (Exp: 2023 Cube)?

Thanks, Team 6741

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-08-09T21:52:05.849Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":219,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":1160.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":439667,"topic_slug":"can-a-limelight-2-detect-objects","display_username":"Yuval","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60096,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6741 Alum / 27995 Co-Captain"},"post_url":"/t/can-a-limelight-2-detect-objects/439667/1","custom_user_title":"6741 Alum / 27995 Co-Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3224161,"name":"Brendan R.","username":"Braykoff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/braykoff/{size}/204536_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-09T22:16:11.405Z","cooked":"

If you are using something like a GRIP pipeline then you have to get the calibration just right for it to work. There are tutorials in the WPILib docs, but unless you get them exactly right it probably won’t be incredibly consistent. Rather, you can recalibrate it according to the lighting at different events (most have died calibration)

If you’re willing to spend the extra money, you can get a Google Coral USB accelerator, basically like a coprocessor that works with the limelight, for under $100. Connect it via USB to the limelight. Then, upload Limelight’s game piece neural network (docs). We’ve never done this, but from my understanding it works very well. The main downside is cost, being +$75 per limelight (although it may be on sale now?)

Braykoff:

recalibrate it according to the lighting at different events

OP can mitigate this somewhat by providing their own light source for more consistency and brighter. We found this especially true for balls which are nearly black to the camera on the bottom half of the ball. Extra light was also useful for a color sensor seeing colored tape on the floor.

Yes, it can. This offseason I have been able to get our 2023 robot’s limelight 2 to detect both the 2023 cube and cone. I was able to do this by turning off the reflective green light and setting up a pipeline to have the limelight look only at the color purple or yellow (1 pipeline per color).

Look at the neural_network_pipelines Getting Started with Neural Networks — Limelight 1.0 documentation
You would need more hardware Google Coral ~$100.

What do you mean by “look only at the color purple or yellow”?

Did You use Special Settings Or You Just Put Specific RGB Setup On The Pipeline?

I just changed the rgb values that the limelight was looking for from green to purple or yellow. It’s one of the sliders when you go to limelight.local

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-08-10T23:39:32.209Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":130,"readers_count":129,"score":36.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":439667,"topic_slug":"can-a-limelight-2-detect-objects","display_username":"Hersh Mepani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":60096,"username":"YuvalCode","name":"Yuval","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yuvalcode/{size}/270549_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52432,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-a-limelight-2-detect-objects/439667/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3229924,"name":"EricRehder","username":"EricRehder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-09-07T00:15:29.672Z","cooked":"

Yup. Listen to Hersh.

Here’s a link to the document
https://docs.limelightvision.io/en/latest/theory.html

Lots of people seem to be enamored with Coral and ML. That’s cool but not needed very often. Usually the pieces are very distinct in color/size for simple recognition. The limelight can easily find the yellow object.

The machine learning comes in if you need to find the “yellow cone that on its side to the right”. And then you could turn your grabber to adjust to the orientation of the cone.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-09-07T00:15:29.672Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":74,"readers_count":73,"score":19.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":439667,"topic_slug":"can-a-limelight-2-detect-objects","display_username":"EricRehder","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.limelightvision.io/en/latest/theory.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Additional Theory — Limelight 1.0 documentation","clicks":11}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-a-limelight-2-detect-objects/439667/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3230004,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-07T11:44:26.778Z","cooked":"

This can also be done in python on the limelight, the example python script is a color script and you can create a range. This would also allow you to create different arrays for cubes and cones an detect them at the same time.
